awd_titl_txt: UNS: Collaborative Research: Impact of Pregnancy on the Mechanics of Vaginal Tissue
awd_abstract_narration:
Pelvic floor disorders (PFDs) encompass a number of medical conditions including stress urinary and fecal incontinence, and pelvic organ prolapse. Although not often discussed, these conditions are extremely common, with more than 50% of parous women having some degree of a PFD during their lifetime and 11% of women requiring surgery. These disorders severely alter the quality of life of women often leading to isolation and depression. To someone not entirely familiar with internal female pelvic anatomy, it may appear that the vagina is no more important than the rectum or urethra in the development of these disorders. However, the vagina is the primary support structure for the urethra, bladder, uterus, and rectum. The vagina is, in turn, supported by a combination of muscle and connective tissues. A direct insult to the vagina and/or its supportive muscles and tissues compromises the function of other pelvic organs. Thus, it should come as no surprise that excessive stretching and tearing of the vagina during labor and vaginal delivery are predisposing factors for the development of PFDs. It is still unclear, however, which of the structural and mechanical alterations that occur in vaginal tissue during pregnancy predispose women to the development of PFDs. 

This collaborative project aims to characterize, for the first time, the mechanisms of stretch induced damage and tear propagation in virgin and pregnant rat vaginal tissue. A comprehensive set of ring tests will be conducted to determine the functional role of the tissue?s constituents (collagen, elastin, and smooth muscle cells) on both the active and passive mechanics of the vagina. Planar biaxial tests will be performed to study the tear propagation process. The results of these tests will guide the development of a new constitutive model that will capture the active and passive mechanical response of the vaginal tissue, including stretch-induced damage. The constitutive model will be implemented into a finite element code especially developed to simulate damage and tear propagation of vaginal tissue. For validation, three-dimensional in-vivo experimental data, which are collected by conducting inflation tests that simulate a birth injury within a state-of-the-art 7T micro-MRI, will be utilized.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
Failure of soft tissues is central to many diseases, including vaginal tear during childbirth. Interestingly, all load-bearing soft-tissues from different locations of human body share a common trait: They are all built with collagen and elastin fibers embedded in a very soft matrix. It is believed that the primary load bearing function for these tissues is accomplished by the fibers, while the non-fibrous matrix provides a scaffold where these fibers can reside. However, precise pathways of load transmission, and the factors that lead to tissue failure are not known. High fidelity computational models, in conjunction with quantitative biomechanical experiments, are required to understand the mechanisms of tissue failure. Current models of soft tissue typically operate at a length scale so that the mechanical contributions of fiber and matrix are averaged. However, existing knowledge of the behavior of engineered fibrous composites, such as fiber reinforced plastics, indicate that interaction between the matrix and fibers is an important factor for the mechanical integrity of these materials. We expected such mechanisms are also important for fibrous soft tissues, and accordingly developed a fiber level computational model for the soft tissue. The novelty of our tissue model is that the structural organization of the protein fibers, typically derived from quantitative image analysis, can be directly incorporated. This feature enabled us to determine mechanics at each fiber and surrounding matrix level as well as at the overall tissue level simultaneously. We tested the predictive capability of the model on the human ascending thoracic aortic tissue, where high quality imaging and biomechanical experimental data was readily available with the co-PI’s lab. Our simulation results revealed the importance of fiber-matrix interaction in governing overall tissue biomechanical response. Specifically, we found that fiber breaks due to anomalous tissue remodeling resulted in focal stresses causing microtears within the tissue, which may lead to ultimate tissue failure. 

At the same time, we developed a macro-scale model of vaginal delivery that included the superficial perineal structures. These are the structures directly surrounding the vaginal opening that are often injured during delivery. Including these structures resulted in higher stretches in the perineal body implying that this perineal body stretch is significantly underestimated by current models that do not include these structures. These findings are more similar to what is observed clinically as the perineum stretches dramatically during fetal head crowning. 

The developments of this research lay the ground work for predictions of tissue failure in this clinical scenario of vaginal delivery. However, the approach can be utilized to understand mechanisms of failure for a variety of tissues. Potential applications, aside from the focus of this award, include aneurysm, premature delivery due to fetal membrane rupture, as well as ligament and tendon tears.

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2018
Modified by: Steven D Abramowitch
